name: Amoebic Liver Abscess
etiology:
Pathogen

Caused by Entamoeba histolytica protozoa via the fecal-oral route (cysts in contaminated water/food). Common in tropical zones (India, Africa).

Pathogenesis

Trophozoites hatch in small bowel -> colonize large bowel -> invade submucosa (flask-shaped ulcers) -> enter portal circulation -> lodge in liver -> liquefactive necrosis.
clinical_features:
Presentation

Insidious onset. Right Upper Quadrant (RUQ) pain (may be pleuritic or radiate to right shoulder). High swinging fever, rigors, night sweats, weight loss.
Signs: Tender hepatomegaly, intercostal tenderness. Jaundice is rare (unless huge).
investigation:
Lab

Leukocytosis, elevated ALP. Serology (Amoebic antibodies) is >95% sensitive.

Imaging

USG: Hypoechoic lesion, ill-defined borders.
Aspiration: 'Anchovy Sauce' pus (odorless, chocolate-colored). It is necrotic liver tissue + blood. Pus is sterile (amoebae are in the wall).
management:
Medical

Metronidazole: 800mg TDS for 10 days (Curative in >90%). Follow with Diloxanide Furoate (luminal agent) to clear gut cysts.

Aspiration/Drainage

Indicated if: 1. Risk of rupture (Left lobe abscess -> Pericarditis), 2. No response to Metronidazole in 72h, 3. Very large (>10cm).

name: Gastric Outlet Obstruction
pathophysiology:
Causes

Benign: Pyloric stenosis secondary to chronic peptic ulcer scarring (fibrosis).
Malignant: Antral Gastric Cancer or Pancreatic Head Cancer invading duodenum.
metabolic_derangement:
Hypochloremic Metabolic Alkalosis

Persistent vomiting of gastric acid (HCl) leads to loss of H+ and Cl-.

Paradoxical Aciduria

Severe dehydration leads to aldosterone release to save Na+. The kidney exchanges Na+ for K+ initially (Hypokalemia), and then for H+. Thus, the kidney excretes acid (H+) into urine despite the blood being alkalotic, to preserve volume.
clinical_features:
History

Vomiting undigested food (non-bilious) eaten 24-48h ago. Weight loss.

Signs

Succussion Splash: Sloshing sound heard on shaking the abdomen >4 hours after a meal.
Visible Peristalsis: Left to right (stomach fighting obstruction). Dehydration.
management:
Resuscitation

1. Wide bore NG tube (Decompression/Lavage).
2. IV Fluids (0.9% Saline + Potassium). Avoid Lactated Ringers initially (lactate -> bicarb -> worsens alkalosis).

Definitive

Benign: Endoscopic Balloon Dilation or Gastrojejunostomy.
Malignant: Stent or Surgery.

name: Shock
definition:
Definition

Acute circulatory failure leading to inadequate tissue perfusion and cellular hypoxia. It is defined by perfusion, not just blood pressure.
classification:
Hypovolemic: Loss of volume (Hemorrhage, Burns). Preload â†“, CO â†“, SVR â†‘.
Cardiogenic: Pump failure (MI, Arrhythmia). Preload â†‘, CO â†“, SVR â†‘.
Obstructive: Physical block (PE, Tamponade).
Distributive: Vasodilation (Sepsis, Anaphylaxis). Preload â†“, CO â†‘ (early), SVR â†“â†“â†“.
clinical_features:
Signs

Tachycardia (early sign). Hypotension (late sign - Class III hemorrhage). Oliguria (<0.5ml/kg/hr). Confusion. Cold/Clammy skin (Hypovolemic/Cardiogenic) vs Warm skin (Early Septic).
management:
Resuscitation Priorities

Hypovolemic: Volume first! (Crystalloids/Blood). Inotropes are harmful in an empty heart.
Cardiogenic: Inotropes (Dobutamine) + Fluid restriction.
Septic: Fluids + Vasopressors (Noradrenaline).

name: Fistula-in-Ano
etiology:
Cryptoglandular Theory

90% of fistulas start as an infection of the anal glands in the intersphincteric space -> Abscess -> Fistula.

Other Causes

Crohn's Disease (complex, multiple), TB, Malignancy, Radiation.
classification:
Parks Classification

1. Intersphincteric (45%): Most common. Tract between sphincters.
2. Trans-sphincteric (30%): Crosses external sphincter.
3. Suprasphincteric: Loops over puborectalis.
4. Extrasphincteric: From rectum to skin (bypass sphincters).
clinical_features:
Goodsall's Rule

Predicts the track path based on external opening.
Anterior Opening: Radial straight track to dentate line.
Posterior Opening: Curved track to posterior midline (6 o'clock).
Exception: Anterior openings >3cm from anus track posteriorly.
investigation:
MRI Pelvis

The gold standard. Essential to map the track relative to the sphincter muscle to prevent incontinence during surgery. EUA (Exam Under Anesthesia) with hydrogen peroxide injection is also used.
management:
Simple (Low)

Fistulotomy (Lay open).

Complex (High/Involving Sphincter)

Seton (thread to drain/cut slowly), LIFT procedure, or Flap. Never cut high sphincter mass (incontinence risk).

name: Diverticular Disease
pathology:
Acquired Diverticula

Herniation of mucosa through muscularis propria at sites of nutrient artery entry (vasa recta).
Location: Sigmoid colon (highest pressure). Rectum is SPARED (has complete muscle coat).
Risk: Low fiber diet, straining.
complications:
1. Diverticulitis: Inflammation/micro-perforation. LIF pain, fever.
2. Perforation: Fecal peritonitis (Hinchey IV).
3. Bleeding: Major cause of massive lower GI bleed (erosion of vasa recta). Painless.
4. Fistula: Colovesical (pneumaturia/UTI).
management:
Acute Diverticulitis

Antibiotics + Bowel rest.

Perforation

Hartmann's Procedure (Resection of sigmoid + End colostomy).

Bleeding

Resuscitation. Most stop spontaneously. Angio-embolization if persistent.

name: Hemorrhoids
anatomy:
Anal Cushions

Normal vascular structures. Three main positions: 3, 7, and 11 o'clock (Left lateral, Right Anterior, Right Posterior).
Internal: Above dentate line (Painless).
External: Below dentate line (Painful if thrombosed).
clinical_features:
Symptoms

Bleeding: Bright red, splash in the pan, separate from stool.
Prolapse: 1st deg (bleed only), 2nd (spontaneous reduction), 3rd (manual reduction), 4th (irreducible).
Pain: ONLY if thrombosed or strangulated.
management:
Conservative

Fiber, fluids.

Office

Rubber Band Ligation (Gold standard for 1st/2nd degree). Sclerotherapy.

Surgical

Hemorrhoidectomy (Milligan-Morgan) for 3rd/4th degree. Stapled Hemorrhoidopexy (PPH).

name: Skin Malignancies
marjolins_ulcer:
Definition

Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC) arising in a chronic wound (burn scar, venous ulcer, sinus) after 10-20 years.

Features

Aggressive. Everted edge. Painful. Metastasizes to regional lymph nodes. Radio-resistant.
Rx: Wide excision.
basal_cell_carcinoma:
BCC (Rodent Ulcer)

Most common skin cancer. Arises from basal layer.
Features: Pearly nodule, rolled edge, telangiectasia, central ulceration.
Behavior: Locally invasive (can destroy bone/cartilage) but almost NEVER metastasizes.
Rx: Excision or Radiotherapy (Radiosensitive).

name: Flail Chest
definition: Fracture of 3 or more adjacent ribs in 2 or more places, creating a floating segment.
pathophysiology:
Paradoxical Movement

Segment moves IN during inspiration and OUT during expiration.

Hypoxia Mechanism

Not just mechanics! The main cause is the underlying Pulmonary Contusion (bruised lung) and pain-induced hypoventilation (splinting).
management:
1. Analgesia: Epidural or Paravertebral block is the priority to allow breathing.
2. Oxygen/CPAP.
3. Intubation: Only if respiratory failure occurs despite analgesia.

name: Intussusception
etiology:
Pathology

Telescoping of bowel (usually ileum into colon).
Children: Idiopathic. Peyer's patch hyperplasia (post-viral) acts as lead point.
Adults: Pathological lead point (Polyp, Tumor, Meckel's) - almost always requires resection.
clinical_features:
Triad

1. Intermittent colicky pain (screaming, drawing legs up).
2. 'Redcurrant jelly' stool (late sign - mucosal ischemia/blood/mucus).
3. Palpable sausage-shaped mass (RUQ) + Empty RIF (Sign of Dance).
investigation:
Ultrasound

'Target sign' or 'Doughnut sign' in transverse section.
management:
Radiological

Air or Barium Enema reduction (First line in kids). Success >80%.

Surgical

If enema fails or peritonitis present. Manual reduction or Resection.

name: Varicocele
anatomy:
Dilatation of pampiniform venous plexus.
Left Sided (90%): Left testicular vein drains vertically into the high-pressure Renal Vein.
Right Sided: Rare. Drains obliquely into IVC.
clinical_features:
Signs

'Bag of worms' feel. Disappears on lying down. Cough impulse.
Red Flag: Sudden onset left varicocele, or ANY right-sided varicocele = Suspect Renal Tumor (invading renal vein).
complications:
Infertility

Increased scrotal temperature impairs spermatogenesis. It is a common treatable cause of male subfertility.
management: Conservative (scrotal support). Embolization or Surgical Ligation if symptomatic or infertility.

name: Hydronephrosis
etiology:
Unilateral

Stone, Stricture, TCC ureter, Pelvi-ureteric junction obstruction (PUJO).

Bilateral

Bladder outflow obstruction (BPH, Urethral valves), Retroperitoneal Fibrosis, Bilateral stones, Advanced Cervical Cancer (frozen pelvis).
clinical_features:
Renal Colic: Loin to groin pain.
Dietl's Crisis: Intermittent severe flank pain/nausea after drinking large fluids (seen in PUJO).
Anuria: Only if complete bilateral obstruction or solitary kidney.
investigation:
USG: First line. Assesses dilatation.
CT KUB: Gold standard for stones.
MAG3 Renogram: Functional test for obstruction vs dilatation.

name: Keloids vs Hypertrophic Scar
keloid:
Features

Overgrowth of dense collagen (Type I & III). Extends beyond original wound margins. No spontaneous regression. High recurrence. Genetic/Dark skin predisposition. Common on sternum, earlobes.
hypertrophic_scar:
Features

Confined within wound margins. Often regresses/improves with time. Occurs at sites of tension (shoulders, knees).
management: Keloid: Intralesional Steroids (Triamcinolone). Excision alone has >50% recurrence rate (must combine with steroids/radiotherapy/pressure).

name: Sterilization & Disinfection
definitions:
Sterilization: Kills ALL organisms + Spores (Autoclave, Ethylene Oxide, Gamma rays).
Disinfection: Reduces load, may not kill spores (Chlorhexidine, Alcohol).
methods:
Autoclave (Moist Heat)

121Â°C for 15mins or 134Â°C for 3mins. Best for metal instruments. Kills spores.

Glutaraldehyde (Cidex)

High-level disinfectant for Endoscopes (heat sensitive).
skin_prep:
Povidone Iodine: Inactivated by organic matter (blood).
Chlorhexidine: Binds to keratin (longer acting). Alcohol-based is best.

name: Metabolic Response to Injury
phases:
Ebb Phase (0-24h)

Shock, hypometabolism, decreased cardiac output. Priority is survival.

Flow Phase

Hypermetabolism, catabolism (muscle wasting for glucose), insulin resistance, acute phase proteins (CRP up, Albumin down).
optimization:
The response is obligatory but can be modified.
1. Analgesia: Blocks afferent neural stimuli.
2. Early Nutrition: Attenuates catabolism.
3. Temp Control: Hypothermia worsens coagulopathy.

name: Routine Biochemical Tests
key_panels:
Full Blood Count (FBC)

  • Hemoglobin: Anemia types: Microcytic (Iron def), Normocytic (Chronic disease), Macrocytic (B12/Folate/Alcohol).
  • WBC: Neutrophilia (Bacterial). Lymphocytosis (Viral). Leukopenia (Sepsis/Chemo).
  • Platelets: Low in Sepsis, DIC, or massive transfusion.

Urea & Electrolytes (U&E)

  • Creatinine: Specific indicator of renal function.
  • Urea: Sensitive to hydration. Isolated rise suggests Upper GI Bleed or Dehydration.
  • Potassium: Hyperkalemia (>5.5) is a surgical emergency.
liver_inflammation:
LFTs

  • Pre-hepatic: High Unconjugated Bilirubin.
  • Hepatocellular: High ALT/AST > ALP.
  • Cholestatic: High ALP/GGT > ALT.
  • Synthetic: Albumin (Chronic) and INR (Acute).

Inflammatory Markers

  • CRP: Acute phase protein. Lags 12-24h behind clinical condition.
  • Amylase/Lipase: >3x upper limit is diagnostic for Pancreatitis.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž The Urea/Creatinine Ratio
A disproportionate rise in Urea compared to Creatinine is the hallmark of Pre-renal Azotemia or Upper GI Bleeding.

name: Routine Imaging Tests
xray_usg:
Plain X-ray

  • Erect CXR: Gold standard for Pneumoperitoneum (free air).
  • Abdominal XR: Diagnostic for Intestinal Obstruction and Toxic Megacolon.

Ultrasound (USG)

  • Uses: Biliary (Gallstones), Renal, Gynae, Scrotum.
  • Pros: No radiation. Cons: Operator dependent.
ct_mri:
CT Scan

  • Uses: Gold standard for Acute Abdomen, Trauma, Cancer Staging.
  • Contrast: IV (Iodine) and Oral.

MRI

  • Uses: MRCP (Biliary), Rectal Cancer Staging, Fistulas.
  • Pros: Superior soft tissue contrast. No radiation.
complications:
Risks

Contrast Induced Nephropathy (CIN): Check eGFR. Hydrate.
Anaphylaxis: Iodine allergy.
Radiation: Avoid CT in pregnancy/children.

name: Endoscopic Procedures
upper_gi:
OGDS (Gastroscopy)

Diagnostic (Ulcer/Ca) and Therapeutic (Variceal Banding).

ERCP

Side-viewing scope for Biliary/Pancreatic ducts. Therapeutic (Stones/Stents). Risk of Pancreatitis (5%).
lower_gi:
Colonoscopy

Visualizes entire colon. Gold standard for CRC/IBD.

Flexible Sigmoidoscopy

Visualizes Rectum/Sigmoid. Quick screen.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž ERCP vs MRCP
MRCP is diagnostic (MRI). ERCP is therapeutic. Use MRCP to find stones, ERCP to remove them.

name: Regions of the Abdomen
regions:
The 9 Regions

Divided by Mid-clavicular lines, Transpyloric (L1), and Transtubercular (L5) planes.
  • Right Hypochondrium: Liver, Gallbladder.
  • Epigastrium: Stomach, Pancreas, Transverse Colon.
  • Left Hypochondrium: Spleen, Stomach Fundus.
  • Flanks (Lumbar): Kidneys, Ascending/Descending Colon.
  • RIF: Cecum, Appendix.
  • LIF: Sigmoid Colon.
clinical:
Pain Localization

RIF: Appendicitis.
Epigastric: PUD, Pancreatitis.
RUQ: Biliary.
LIF: Diverticulitis.
landmark:
ðŸ’Ž Transpyloric Plane (L1)
Contains: Pylorus, Pancreas neck, SMA origin, Portal vein formation, Renal hila.

name: Anatomy of the Stomach
structure:
Parts

Cardia, Fundus, Body, Antrum, Pylorus.

Blood Supply

Lesser Curvature: Left Gastric + Right Gastric.
Greater Curvature: Left Gastroepiploic + Right Gastroepiploic.
Fundus: Short Gastric arteries (Splenic).
nerve_supply:
Vagus (CN X)

Anterior Trunk: Left Vagus. Posterior Trunk: Right Vagus.
Nerve of Latarjet: Supplies antrum (pump).
lymphatics: Virchow's Node: Left Supraclavicular node. Drains stomach via Thoracic Duct (Troisier's sign).

name: Anatomy of Hepatobiliary System
liver_biliary:
Liver

Couinaud Segments (I-VIII). Caudate Lobe (I) drains directly to IVC.

Biliary Tree

Hepatic Ducts -> Common Hepatic Duct + Cystic Duct -> Common Bile Duct (CBD).
calots_triangle:
Boundaries

Superior: Liver edge. Medial: Common Hepatic Duct. Lateral: Cystic Duct.
Content: Cystic Artery. (Critical view in Cholecystectomy).
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Moynihan's Hump
Tortuous Right Hepatic Artery looping into Calot's triangle. Bleeding risk.

name: Anatomy of Alimentary Tract
small_bowel:
Jejunum vs Ileum

Jejunum: Thick wall, wide lumen, long vasa recta.
Ileum: Thin wall, Peyer's patches, short vasa recta, fatty mesentery.
large_bowel:
Features

Taeniae Coli, Haustra, Appendices Epiploicae.
Supply: SMA (Midgut) & IMA (Hindgut) connected by Marginal Artery of Drummond.
watershed:
ðŸ’Ž Ischemia Risk
Griffith's Point (Splenic flexure) and Sudeck's Point (Rectosigmoid) are watershed areas prone to ischemia.

name: Anatomy of Genitourinary System
kidney_ureter:
Kidneys

Retroperitoneal (T12-L3). Hilum: Vein, Artery, Pelvis (Ant-Post).

Ureters

Run on Psoas. Cross over Iliac vessels. Pass under Uterine artery/Vas deferens.
constrictions:
Stone Impaction Sites

1. PUJ (Pelvi-ureteric junction).
2. Pelvic Brim (Crossing Iliacs).
3. VUJ (Vesico-ureteric junction - narrowest).
referral:
ðŸ’Ž Referred Pain
Kidney (T10-L1) -> Loin. Ureter -> Groin/Scrotum/Labia (Genitofemoral n.).

name: Inguinal Canal Anatomy
boundaries:
MALT Mnemonic

Muscle (Roof): Internal Oblique.
Aponeurosis (Ant): External Oblique.
Ligament (Floor): Inguinal.
Transversalis (Post): Fascia.
contents:
Male: Spermatic Cord + Ilioinguinal Nerve.
Female: Round ligament + Ilioinguinal Nerve.
Note: Nerve is ON TOP of cord.
clinical:
Deep Ring: Mid-inguinal point (Indirect Hernia).
Hesselbach's Triangle: Medial to Inf Epigastric vessels (Direct Hernia).
